annotation:
[('Ran away with the passing days
You’ll be a movie-star
Next time', [['She loves movies, and the idea of being a movie star, and gets caught up in her fantasies. However, the speaker says that this will happen “next time.” This gives a sense that it will only happen in her dreams, and that she will never move beyond the dingy projection booth.']]), ('Bette Davis plays', [['Bette Davis was one of the most well-known actresses from 1930 through 1940. She appeared in movies such as “All This and Heaven Too,” and “Of Human Bondage,” the movie that made her a star.']]), ('When you were just a kid you loved
To go to movies in the afternoon
And so you left the factory
And got a job in the projection-room', [['She decides to leave factory work for a job at a movie theatre.
The projection room is the space in the back of an old movie theatre where someone would sit and change the reels of movie film. In the hierarchy of movie-related jobs, it was basically at the bottom (with movie stars like Bette Davis at the top).']])]

title: Modern Times
lyrics:
Modern Times LyricsHello old friend, what a strange coincidence to find you
It's been fifteen years since we last met, but I still recognised you
So call the barman over here, and let us fill our glasses
And drink a toast to olden times where all our memories lie
Where all our memories lie

Do you remember the time we were young?
Lowly, lowly, low
Outside the window the frosty moonlight hung
On the midnight snow
So we pulled our scarves around our faces in the night
Huddled on the doorsteps where the fairylights shone bright
Singing Christmas carols while our breath hung in the light
It all comes back like yesterday
It almost seems like yesterday
Do you remember the changes as we grew?
Slowly, slowly, slow
Sneaking in the back way into movies after school
For the evening show
Chasing skinny blue jean girls across the building-site
Checking out the dance floor while the band played "Hold Me Tight"
See the blonde one over there: I bet she'd be alright
It all comes back like yesterday
It almost seems like yesterday

While I talked he sat and he never made a sound
Staring at the glass beside me
Hey old friend, tell me what's on your mind?
Silence grows on you like ivy
Ivy

Do you remember the church across the sands?
Holy, holy, ho
You stood outside and planned to travel the lands
Where the pilgrims go
So you packed your world up inside a canvas sack
Set off down the highway with your rings and Kerouac
Someone said they saw you in Nepal a long time back
Tell me why you look away
Don't you have a word to say?
You might also likeHe said, "I don't remember ... I Don't want to remember
In fact I've heard too much already
I don't want to think, just leave me here to drink
Wrapped up in the warmth of New York City
Oh, oh, it seems you just don't know
And you just don't understand me
I've got no use for the tricks of modern times
They tangle all my thoughts like ivy
Ivy"

So I left him, and I went out to the street
Lowly, lowly, low
Where the red light girls were coming after me
Forty dollar show
All across the city's heart the lights were coming on
The hotel lift softly hummed a Cole Porter song
If I went to look for him I knew he would be gone
A picture-card of yesterday
A photograph of yesterday
And far off in a deserted part of town
The shadows like a silent army
Flooded out the rooms in pools of blue and brown
And stuck to all the walls like ivy
Ivy
Ivy1Embed
annotation:
[('And stuck to all the walls like ivy', [['Ivy on a wall suggests that the wall has been there a very long time. Like moss growing on a stone, ivy indicates that nothing has really changed there. At the same time, ivy, by its clinging, gradually destroys the walls that it covers. Clearly the old friend does not want to be tied down by clinging vines.']]), ('Oh, oh, it seems you just don’t know
 And you just don’t understand me', [['This is an accusation, of course, but even taken non-critically, it suggests that the singer’s life has really not changed much, while his friend who went out perhaps to see the world and find himself, has experienced things, good and bad, that would be incomprehensible to the one who stayed near home.']]), ('He said, ”I don’t remember ... I Don’t want to remember
 In fact I’ve heard too much already
 I don’t want to think, just leave me here to drink', [['Here the old friend opens up as much as he ever will in this ballad. He finally speaks, but only to say that he doesn’t want to speak, or rather he doesn’t want to remember or think.']]), ('Tell me why you look away
 Don’t you have a word to say?', [['We might assume from this stanza that the old friend has been on some kind of spiritual quest. At this point, it seems unlikely that he was in the military. But the thousand-yard stare remains and its cause is still a mystery.']]), ('Staring at the glass beside me
 Hey old friend, tell me what’s on your mind?
 Silence grows on you like ivy', [['Here we finally see the old friend’s reaction to the narrator’s reminiscences; what soldiers call a “thousand yard stare”.  So much has happened in his life since “yesterday” that the old friendship is apparently so distant that it might as well have been someone else’s life.']]), ('Set off down the highway with your rings and Kerouac', [['Jack Kerouac was an American author of the Beat Generation. One of his most famous novels was “On The Road,” which discussed travel and freedom from society. It would have inspired his friends wish to travel the world.
The full text can be found here.']]), ('Where the red light girls were coming after me
 Forty dollar show', [['The “red light girls” are prostitutes. This could be a reference to Amsterdam’s Red Light District.']]), ('The hotel lift softly hummed a Cole Porter song', [['Cole Porter was a songwriter and composer active in the 1930’s and 40’s. He was one of Broadway’s main songwriters, and wrote for many of the era’s most popular musicals.

There’s a whole site dedicated to him!']]), ('While the band played “Hold Me Tight”', [['“Hold Me Tight” is a song by the Beatles. It was the 9th track on their 1963 album With The Beatles.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qlKzsR2HREc']]), ('And far off in a deserted part of town
 The shadows like a silent army', [['The night gradually swallows the city. In this case the shadow could represent oblivion or the city’s methods of escapism. It could also represent the friend’s growing melancholy.']])]

title: Elvaston Place
lyrics:
Elvaston Place LyricsElvaston Place
A run-down basement in South Ken
Hiding your face
Behind the railings in the rain
Stony steps to a small grey herd
Of dustbins blinking in the sunlight
Our yesterday lives
Crouched by the fireside
In Elvaston Place

Holes in the lace-
Curtains, splintery window frames
A small furnished space
We never knew the landlord's name
Electric bar to warm your winter toes
Evening paper for the bath mat
Watching the face
Happy beside me
In Elvaston Place
The city's spreading like a stony tide across the countryside
I live alone now in London town
Cars and buses everywhere, they hide the sun and eat the air
You need a friend when it gets you down
All the money that I've ever owned
I'd give it all tomorrow
If I could lay happy beside you
In Elvaston Place

Elvaston Place
I stopped to look at you today
New whitewashed face
Behind the railings in the rain
You once held a love of mine
She changed just like the weather
The Kensington skies go on for ever
In Elvaston PlaceYou might also likeEmbed
annotation:

A run-down basement in South Ken
Hiding your face
Behind the railings in the rain', [['Al Stewart lived at Elvaston Place in South West London with his girlfriend Mandi, and they shared an open relationship– something that bothered Stewart quite a bit at the the time. Their relationship lasted a couple years, though, and this love song is about her.']])]

title: Lord Grenville
lyrics:
Lord Grenville LyricsGo and tell Lord Grenville that the tide is on the turn
It's time to haul the anchor up and leave the land astern
We'll be gone before the dawn returns
Like voices on the wind

Go and tell Lord Grenville that our dreams have run aground
There's nothing here to keep us in this shanty town
None of us are caring where we're bound
Like voices on the wind

And come the day you'll hear them saying
"They're throwing it all away"
Nothing more to say
Just throwing it all away
Go and fetch the captain's log and tear the pages out
We're on our way to nowhere now, can't bring the helm about
None of us are left in any doubt
We won't be back again

Send a message to the fleet, they'll search for us in vain
We won't be there among the reaches of the Spanish Main
Tell the ones we left home not to wait

We won't be back again
(Won't be back again...)

And come the day you'll hear them saying
"They're throwing it all away"
Nothing more to say
Just throwing it all away

Our time is just a point along a line
That runs forever with no end
I never thought that we would come to find
Ourselves upon these rocks again
Oh no...

Go and tell Lord Grenville that the tide is on the turnYou might also likeEmbed

[('Our time is just a point along a line

The fishing boats go out across the evening water
Smuggling guns and arms across the Spanish border

annotation: [('Turns the rifles into silver on the border', [['Silver has been a leading production of Spain ever since Roman times. Rio Tinto, one of the world’s largest mining companies today had its roots in Spanish silver. Silver can buy guns.']]), ('Smuggling guns and arms across the Spanish border', [['This song is fundamentally about the Spanish revolution.']]), ('From Africa the winds they talk of changes coming', [['In Africa, in particular, the early 20th century was a time of unwinding of the old Colonial order. If they’re running, then territory is changing hands between different countries. This is another indicator of the change that concerns the speaker.']])]

title: Midas Shadow
lyrics:
Midas Shadow LyricsYou got your ticket and your hotel keys
And your overnight bag at your feet
You’re looking down on the tropical trees
While the Spanish maids pick up the sheets
Conquistador in search of gold
For all the jackdaw reasons
The Midas shadow that’s so hard to please
And follows wherever you go

Nothing ventured, nothing gained they said
So you played for the winner takes all
And tossed the dice high up and craned your head
To see how the numbers would fall
You stole the game so easily
Your luck ran with the seasons
But still the shadow that the night won’t free
Just follows wherever you go
Another day, another boarding card
As you wait for your seat on the plane
The movie runs but you’re still working hard
And you don’t touch your food or champagne
I know that when your well runs dry
You’ll want to know the reason
The empty night will bring you no reply
As it follows wherever you goYou might also like2Embed
annotation:
[('But still the shadow that the night won’t free
 Just follows wherever you go', [['The Midas shadow seems to be a compulsion to turn everything someone touches into gold – for instance while gambling. Even after a successful night of gambling (in which the person being described ‘stole the game so easily’), the urge to keep on gambling follows them wherever they go.']]), ('Jackdaw', [['The jackdaw is a bird in the crow family. Like magpies (another bird in the crow family), jackdaws are known to show interest in shiny objects (e.g., jewellery). ‘Jackdaw reasons’ presumably refers to someone being interested in shiny objects (such as gold) just for the sake it.']]), ('Conquistador', [['Conquistador is Spanish and Portuguese for ‘conqueror’. The term is used to refer to soldiers of the Spanish and Portuguese Empires. In the 15th to 18th centuries, they conquered territory, opened trade routes and colonised part of the world.']]), ('Midas', [['King Midas is a Greek mythological figure.

Dionysus – the Greek god of wine, fertility, vegetation, ecstasy and festivity – granted Midas a wish. Midas asked that everything he touches would turn into gold, an ability he initially enjoys. But when Midas sits down to eat and finds that even the food on his table turns into gold (and thereby becomes inedible) when he touches it, he regrets his wish and asks Dionysus for it be reverted. Dionysus tells him to wash in the river Pactolus. When Midas does so, the river sands turn into gold.']])]

title: Sand in Your Shoes
lyrics:
Sand in Your Shoes LyricsYou always were a city kid
Though you were country raised
And back in some forgotten time
We shared the cold north days
But the simple life was not your style
And you just had to escape
So it's goodbye to my lady of the islands

On Remembrance Day the bands all played
The bells pealed through the park
And you lay there by the "Do Not" signs
And shamed them with your spark
Now winter moans in old men's bones
As the day falls into dark
And it's goodbye to my lady of the islands
It was just like this

Behind the kisses you so soon swept away
Oh I always knew
That some day you'd
Be bound to just get pulled away

The summer sun beats on and on
The shops swim in the heat
And you're standing by the traffic signs
With taxis at your feet
Oh I know that in your city skin
You're feeling more complete
So it's goodbye to my lady of the islands

No I never got the letters
That you said you'd send me
So it's goodbye to my lady of the islandsYou might also likeEmbed
annotation: [('And you lay there by the “Do Not” signs\n And shamed them with your spark', [['In these lines the protagonist remembers a time with his lover where she was smoking in a forbidden area.']]), ('On Remembrance Day the bands all played\n The bells pealed through the park', [['Remembrance Day, or Remembrance Sunday, is a holiday held in the United Kingdom (along with former members of the British Commonwealth) on the second Sunday in November, to commemorate those who lost their lives in World War I, along with subsequent military conflicts. Remembrance Day takes place on the second Sunday in November due to the signing of the armistice (peace treaty) that took place on November 11, 1918 to end World War I. Traditional Remembrance Day occurrences include  the wearing of the red poppy (many start wearing their poppies 11 days beforehand), a televised remembrance service, and as mentioned in these lines, the playing of bands and the ringing of bells, the latter signifying freedom and peace.']])]

title: If It Doesn't Come Naturally Leave It
lyrics:
If It Doesn’t Come Naturally, Leave It LyricsNothing that's forced can ever be right
If it doesn't come naturally, leave it
That's what she said as she turned out the light
And we bent our backs as slaves of the night
Then she lowered her guard and showed me the scars
She got from trying to fight
Saying oh, you'd better believe it

Well I'm up to my neck in the crumbling wreckage
Of all that I wanted from life
When I looked for respect all I got was neglect
Though I swallowed the line as a sign of the times
But dealing a jack from the back of the pack
They said-"You lose again"
Oh, I said, who needs it?
Well don't get me wrong now I tried to get on
With the jokers that got in my way
And I put on a smile and I tried all the while to be straight
But they just wanted more all the time and I'm sure
That you know what I mean when I say
That I'm sick of the touch and there's only so much you can take

Well nothing that's real is ever for free
And you just have to pay for it sometime
She said it before, she said it to me
I suppose she believed there was nothing to see
But the same old four imaginary walls
She built for living inside
I said oh, you just can't mean it

Well there was never a doubt that she had to get out
She was just looking around for a way
In the pit of the night there was nowhere to hide any more
She was out on a limb, she was reaching for things
That she wanted, but just couldn't say
And she had to be sure that she wouldn't get caught like before

Well nothing that's forced can ever be right
If it doesn't come naturally, leave it
That's what she said as she turned out the light
And she may have been wrong, and she may have been right
But I woke with the frost, and noticed she'd lost
The veil that covered her eyes
I said oh, you can leave itYou might also likeEmbed

title: Flying Sorcery
lyrics:
Flying Sorcery LyricsWith your photographs of Kitty Hawk
And the biplanes on your wall
You were always Amy Johnson
From the time that you were small
No schoolroom kept you grounded
While your thoughts could get away
You were taking off in Tiger Moths
Your wings against the brush-strokes of the day
Are you there?
On the tarmac with the winter in your hair
By the empty hangar doors, you stop and stare
Leave the oil-drums behind you, they won't care
Oh, are you there?
Oh, you wrapped me up in a leather coat
And you took me for a ride
We were drifting with the tail-wind
When the runway came in sight
The clouds came up to gather us
And the cockpit turned to white
When I looked, the sky was empty
I suppose you never saw the landing-lights
Are you there?
In your jacket with the grease stain and the tear
Caught up in the slipstream of the dare
The compass rose will guide you anywhere
Oh, are you there?

The sun comes up on Icarus as the night-birds sail away
And lights the maps and diagrams
That Leonardo made
You can see Faith, Hope and Charity
As they bank above the fields
You can join the flying circus
You can touch the morning air against your wheels
Are you there?
Do you have a thought for me that you can share?
Oh I never thought you'd take me unawares
Just call me if you ever need repairs
Oh, are you there?You might also likeEmbed
annotation: [('Just call me if you ever need repairs', [['Al Stewart explains this line as a metaphor between lovers parted. Repairs representing a repair in their relationship and the line as a whole representing feelings that linger.']]), ('Leonardo', [['This may refer to Leonardo da Vinci, an Italian polymath (1452–1519). Leonardo is best known as a painter, but he also worked in engineering and was fascinated by the possibility of human flight. He produced writing and sketches that deal with flying machines, the nature of air and bird flight.']]), ('Tarmac', [['Tarmacadam (or tarmac for short) is road surfacing material that combines macadam (crushed stones; the technique was named for its inventor, John L. McAdam), tar, and sand. In the early 20th century, the term started being used generally for ‘runway’ (at least in Great Britain).']]), ('Biplanes', [['A biplane is an aircraft with two wings stacked on top of each other. The Wright Flyer – the first powered, controlled aeroplane to fly (cf. annotation to Kitty Hawk) – had a biplane wing arrangement, just like many other planes in the early days of aviation.']]), ('Kitty Hawk', [['The first controlled, sustained flight of a powered, heavier-than-air aircraft was made by the Wright brothers on 17 December 1903. The flight took place just a few miles south of Kitty Hawk, North Carolina.']]), ('Faith, Hope and Charity', [['At the Siege of Malta in 1940, the Hal Far flight of the RAF provided air cover. Three Gloster Sea Gladiator fighters, named Faith, Hope, and Charity, were said to provide air cover (though, in reality, many aircraft were involved).']]), ('Tiger Moths', [['The de Havilland Tiger Moth is a biplane produced in the 1930s, used to train RAF pilots.']]), ('Amy Johnson', [['Amy Johnson (1903-1941) was a British aviator. She was the first female pilot to fly from the UK to Australia.']])]

Nothing was stranger than being yourself

Love was a rollaway
Just a cajole away
Mist on a summer's day
Nothing was clear
Love was a smile away
Just a defile away

No-one came near

Love was a rollaway

title: One Stage Before
lyrics:
One Stage Before LyricsIt seems to me as though I've been upon this stage before
And juggled away the night for the same old crowd
These harlequins you see with me, they too have held the floor
As here once again they strut and they fret their hour
I see those half-familiar faces in the second row
Ghost-like with the footlights in their eyes
But where or when we met like this last time I just don't know
It's like a chord that rings and never dies
For infinity

And now these figures in the wings with all their restless tunes
Are waiting around for someone to call their names
They walk the backstage corridors and prowl the dressing-rooms
And vanish to specks of light in the picture-frames
But did they move upon the stage a thousand years ago
In some play in Paris or Madrid?
And was I there among them then, in some travelling show
And is it all still locked inside my head
For infinity
And some of you are harmonies to all the notes I play
Although we may not meet still you know me well

While others talk in secret keys and transpose all I say
And nothing I do or try can get through the spell
So one more time we'll dim the lights and ring the curtain up
And play again like all the times before
But far behind the music you can almost hear the sounds
Of laughter like the waves upon the shores
Of infinityYou might also likeEmbed

annotation:
[('Marie Celeste', [['The Mary Celeste was an American merchant vessel which was discovered adrift and desert in the Atlantic Ocean of the Azores Islands in 1872. Many hypothesis such as mutiny, piracy or natural causes were advanced, which reached no clear conclusion.

Due to its mysterious outcome, Sir Arthur Conan Doyle wrote a short story based on the vessel, which misspelled its name as ‘Marie Celeste’, just like Al Stewart mentions in this verse.']]), ('Oh come away from the day, here I stay

annotation:
[('And caught by the first rays of dawn', [['If a sailor was lost at sea, the only sure way of finding their direction was to find the north star. The sailor is scanning the meridian to try to find this north star. When he is “caught by the first rays of dawn,” if means that he will no longer be able to find the star and get back on course. Despite his science and logic, he is still lost.



(A reference for the next time you’re lost at sea.)']]), ('The man for all seasons
Is lost beneath the storm', [['The storm refers to the rise of Protestantism, while the sun would refer to Henry VIII, who ordered his beheading.

Sir Thomas Moore was seen as a “man for all seasons” for his ability to maintain a political career in tumultuous times, but even he is eventually swept away by the storm.']]), ('And put our defeats down to chance or experience
And try once again for the light
Some wait for the waters of fortune to cover them
Some just see the tides of ill chance running over them', [['The Age of Reason valued logic and rationality above all else. However, the chorus argues that rationality will give you “no reprieve.” This verse changes tack, and instead looks at chance and fortune. Pessimistically, neither course brings success. The “man for all seasons” is “lost behind the sun,” while those looking for luck see “the tides of ill chance running over them.”']]), ('Lanterns to turn back the night', [['The Age of Reason was also known as the Age of Enlightenment. Since then, “light” or brightness has become synonymous with the good or rational, and darkness has become representative of evil or chaos. Their gains are seen as points of light (instances of goodness or rationality) that will combat the chaos and irrationality of the rest of the world.']]), ('Some wait for the boats that still row to Valhallah
Well, you should try to accept what the fates are unfolding', [['Valhalla is the grand hall in Norse mythology where great warriors are sent when they die. In contrast to the previous lines, this references older “pagan” religions that held sway in Europe before Christianity. Similarly, the fates, another set of older gods, are portrayed as the ones with real power.']]), ('Some call on Jehovah
Some cry out to Allah', [['Jehovah refers to the God of Christianity and Judaism, while Allah is the Muslim God.  In the time period of the play, this would have encompassed the religions of basically everyone in England at the time. Even though the play spends a great deal of time with the split of Western Christianity into Catholic and Protestant, Stewart only mentions one Christian God, perhaps making a comment on lack of differences between the Anglican church and the Catholic church that More died in defense of.']]), ('A sailor through the darkness
He scans the meridian', [['The meridian is an imaginary plane in the sky, tracing a line in the sky from north to south. For a sailor, it would have been used for navigation, and would have been important at night when trying to find the north star.']]), ('While the man for all seasons
Is lost behind the sun', [['The play discusses the battle between conscience and identity. More is presented as a “man for all seasons” in that he keeps his core values through many events and political turmoils. However, More is eventually beheaded because he sticks to his principles- he is “lost behind the sun” and (in the next verse) “lost beneath the storm.”']]), ('Only to find there was no reprieve
Would you still be a man for all seasons?', [['This follows the themes of the play, asking if the arrival of a world completely ruled by natural law and logic (and age of reason) would allow individuals to retain their core beliefs. The lack of reprieve means that this “age of reason,” for all its logic, would not free individuals from conscience (another one of the themes dealt with in the play.)']]), ('What if you reached the age of reason', [['Also known as the Age of Rationalism, the Age of Reason was the philosophical precursor to the Enlightenment (or simply the beginning of the Enlightenment, depending on your perspective). annotation:
[('Our time is wasting in the wind', [['When this line is sung, the guitar melody interrupts the vocal line between “our time” and “is wasting in the wind.” The melody sounds a lot like wind, and gives the aural effect of interrupting time with a gust of wind, mirroring the meaning of the line.']]), ('Marat your days are numbered', [['Jean-Paul Marat was a journalist and political scientist active during the French Revolution. He supported the sans-culottes, a radical left-wing group made up primarily of urban laborers, who argued for political and economic equality for the urban poor. His support of this faction aided the decline of the Girondins (another revolutionary faction). When they fell from power, one of their members sought revenge and killed Marat while he was taking a bath.']]), ('Oh you sit and talk all through the night
 But there’s just no place to go', [['The beginning of the French Revolution was largely controlled by the new middle class (merchants and lawyers dissatisfied with their relegation to the Third Estate), and philosophers influenced by the Age of Enlightenment. These philosophers led the more conservative beginnings of the Revolution, publishing the Declaration of the Rights of Man and placing an emphasis on the ideas of the revolution- “talk[ing] all though the night.”

As the revolution progressed, and was met with the bloody violence of the Reign of Terror, these philosophers would have felt increasingly trapped, both intellectually and politically.']]), ('The ghost of revolution
 Still prowls the Paris streets', [['Although the French revolution didn’t succeed in expanding full equality to all members of the third estate, it make some lasting reforms. They did succeed in limiting the powers of the monarchy, although they did not end the monarchy itself (it resurfaced fully after the death of Napoleon II).

One of the most important reforms was Napoleon’s institution of a consistent, written legal code, which he enforced throughout his empire.']]), ('It speaks inside the cheap red wine
 Of cafe summer nights
 Its red and amber voices
 Call the cars at traffic lights', [['Here the imagery jumps from the late 18th century to modern times. Red wine and cafes are often associated with the stereotypical idea of Paris, and mention of cars completes the urban scenery. The “red and amber voices” makes the scene less ordinary, as if the “ghost of revolution” is the one whispering.']]), ('Down all the restless centuries
 It wanders incomplete', [['In the same way that the American Revolution influenced the ideas set fourth in the French Revolution, the French Revolution influenced and inspired other revolutions in colonies around the world. The “restless centuries” would refer to the other future revolutions it inspires, while it would be considered incomplete because neither the French Revolution or the other later revolutions fully succeeded.']]), ('Inside the midnight councils
 The lamps are burning low', [['These lines reference the National Assemblies that convened to abolish the absolute monarchy. Most important was their “Declaration of the Rights of Man,” which drew on the ideas set forth in the Constitution to secure basic rights for the non-aristocratic.

This could also refer to the later Constituent Assembly, which declared the right to self-determination, or the 1792 Convention, which established the republic.']]), ('It echoes
 Through the lonely palace of Versailles', [['After Louis XVI was forced from Versailles in 1789 (taken to Paris to feel the suffering of the common man), Versailles would have been left empty as the rest of the aristocracy tried to seem as nonexistent as possible.']]), ('We burned out their mansions
 In the name of Robespierre', [['Robespierre oversaw the later, more radical stage of the French revolution. This time period was known as the Reign of Terror, and was characterized by the many beheadings- mainly of aristocracy, but also of those who fell behind the radicalism of the revolution. As the aristocracy fled the country, or were executed, their property and possessions would have been seized as mob rule gained more weight than law.']]), ('The Kings have all departed
 There servants are nowhere', [['By October 1789 the King and his family were forced out of Versailles and made to go to Paris where a new Constitution was being drafted. Versailles was seen as a symbol of their luxury and isolation, so they were sent to Paris to remind them of the struggles of the common people.

By 1791 the French king was so worried by the revolution that he decided to flee the country. He fled with his family to allies at a military camp in Northern France, but was recognized and captured before reaching safety (one of the downsides to putting your likeness on every coin in the country). He and his wife, Marie Antoinette, were captured and returned to Paris, where they were later beheaded.



Source.']])]
