(a famous Christian expression) John 20:21']]), ('And there’s Churchill’s hiccup
 And we can’t leave it up in the air', [['There’s a legend that Sir Winston Churchill had eaten (and drank) heavily before a negotiation session leading up to the Treaty of Versailles. Supposedly, he hiccuped and his hand jerked while drawing the border of what is today Jordan, producing the strange jog in its border.

It’s almost surely untrue, but it fits his character so well that it has lived on in history.']]), ('Lawrence of Arabia is waiting in the wings
 He’s got some Arab sheikhs and kings
 And we’re in debt to them somehow', [['T.E. Lawrence (1888 – 1935)

Now famously known as “Lawrence of Arabia”, T.E. Lawrence was born on 16 August 1888 in Wales.

After graduating with honors from Oxford in 1910, he assisted in archeology for the British Museum in Iraq. When war broke out with Germany in 1914, he was posted to the Military Intelligence Department in Cairo.



Lawrence was a strong voice for independent Arab nation states.']]), ('Still you know that to the victors go the spoils
 Such a great responsibility to make it fair
 And there must be some reparations now
 And don’t forget the oil', [['In 1916 the Arabs revolted against the Turkish Empire, and T.E. Lawrence was sent to Mecca on a fact-finding mission. He ultimately became the British liaison officer to the Arabs.

After the war, Lawrence served in the British Delegation to the Paris Peace Conference, where he worked for the cause of Arab independence. Despite his efforts, Syria, Palestine and Iraq all came under French and British rule (and the British and French got a steady supply of oil).']]), ('But Clemenceau turns to Lloyd George
 And says ”You know that
 God himself had only ten”', [['Supposedly a quote from the Prime Minister of France, George Clémenceau, and a sarcastic reference to Wilson as being akin to Moses.']]), ('Woodrow Wilson waves his fourteen points around
 And says ”The time to act is now
 Won’t get this opportunity again”', [['President Woodrow Wilson fought for his fourteen point plan and the League of Nations.

His fourteen point plan was the high road, and while it was a beautiful concept, it was too utopian to become real.  It included ideas like:


True Transparency in Government: Open covenants of peace, openly arrived at,  frankly and in the public view.
No more Lusitanias: Freedom of navigation on the seas, outside of territorial waters.
World Wide Free Trade: The removal of all economic barriers and the establishment of equality of trade among nations.
Strategic Arms Limitation Treaty v1.O: Guarantees that national armaments will be reduced to the lowest point consistent with domestic safety.



In the end, Wilson’s fourteen points and U.S. participation in the League of Nations crashed and burned on the U.S. Senate floor.']]), ('Today I’m carried by a league of notions
 (It’s a league of notions)
 By a league of notions
 I don’t think I quite understand', [['The League of Nations formed after World War I to promote cooperation, peace and security among nations. The basis for the League is found in the Treaty of Versailles, which provided for such an international assembly. The United States, which failed to ratify the Treaty of Versailles, never became a member.

Based in Geneva, the League was useful, for a time, in settling minor disputes.  But it was unable to stop major acts of aggression, such as Japan’s invasion of Manchuria in 1931, and Italy’s invasion of Ethiopia in 1936). It collapsed early in World War II, and was dissolved in 1946.']]), ('And every single nationality and principality
 Have come for a piece of the pie', [['As was common practice in all previous wars, the victors got to redraw the borders; more for the winners, less for the losers. The problem with this war was, there were just too many winners and every one of them wanted a piece of the action.

Many believe the Treaty of Versailles was unfair to Germany and sowed the seeds for WW2.  Of the 466 articles in the treaty, 440 of them describe the various punishments on Germany. For example:


Germany had to accept blame for starting the war.  That provided the justification for Germany being required to pay £11.3 billion in reparations. That was reduced  in 1921 to £5 billion).
Germany was forbidden to have submarines or an air force.  She was limited to six battleships and her Army could be no more than 100,000 men.
Germany could not place any troops in the Rhineland, a strip of land 50 miles wide, next to France.
Germany lost territory in Europe and all her  colonies were given to Britain and France.']])]

annotation:
[('Thinking back on all the times we had', [['This sense of nostalgia is perhaps somewhat ironic, given that the Bolshevik revolution was, in part, a decidedly anti-nostalgic movement. Far from having a romanticized view of Russia’s past and then-present, they viewed the old Tsarist Russia as an oppressive and antiquated system in need of being violently abolished. But now that the singer is in a worse place than he was before (a position not unlike that of Russian royals who lost everything to the Revolution), he suddenly pines for the past.']]), ('And I won’t make up a story
 ’Cause you know the truth so well', [['This line is rather ironic in view of the Soviet’s love of propaganda and twisting or distorting facts in their favor. Effectively, “making up a story” was a favorite tool of the Soviets when they were in power.']]), ('They’ve given me my ticket
 To this place beyond the grave', [['The narrator, be he Trotsky or some other Soviet, has evidently been made to pay for his role in the Red Army’s atrocities, being consigned to Hell.']]), ('We’re sharpening our pitchforks
 And we’re heating up the ends', [['The communists Stalin betrayed are patiently waiting for him to die so that he can join them in Hell-and they can get their revenge. Of course, the pitchfork is the traditional weapon of demons and other infernal denizens in western popular conception.']]), ('There’s Kamenev, Zinoviev
 Bukharin and the rest', [['Three of the most important figures to fall to Stalin’s purges, and originally among the most important figures in the early Bolshevik party (Kamenev and Zinoviev were both members of the first Soviet politburo). Conspicuously absent from this list is Leon Trotsky, probably the most famous of Stalin’s political opponents (and ultimately victims), and suggesting that he may be the narrator of the song.']]), ('And cast us one by one over the side', [['One by one, most of the old Bolsheviks who had been in the party since before the Civil War were removed from their positions and then executed by Stalin, quickly eliminating potential threats to his power.']]), ('And he steered us through the shadows
 Upon an angry tide', [['Many Communists view Stalin’s assuming leadership of the USSR as a turning point, after which its official mission of building socialism and transitioning to communism was corrupted and replaced by a brutal dictatorship. Thus, Stalin steered the USSR ‘through the shadows’.']]), ('When the captain took the fever
 We were hijacked by the mate', [['Lenin, leader of the Bolsheviks (and thus the ‘captain’ of the Soviet ‘ship of state’ referred to in the previous line) fell ill in the early 1920s and died soon after, leaving a power vacuum in the party which various Bolsheviks then fought each other to fill. Lenin did not wish for Stalin to take over administration of the Soviet state, but this ended up happening anyway (thus they were ‘hijacked’ by Stalin, the ‘mate’.']]), ('We all set off together
 On this sorry ship of state', [['The speaker remembers the early days of the revolution, when the Bolshevik party took control of Russia and set her on a course towards socialism. Clarifying that they all ‘set off together’ emphasizes the comradeship of the Bolshevik leadership, making Stalin’s later betrayal more poignant. https://s3.amazonaws.com/filepicker-images-rapgenius/RSAGBpdlQ86WDBZA9Pnu_Kustodiev_The_Bolshevik.jpgThe ‘ship of state’ is an old metaphor, comparing the administration of government to piloting a shape.']]), ('But it’s kind of hot and smoky
 In this ante-room to Hell', [['The speaker has ended up on the less pleasant side of the afterlife-considering he was evidently an important figure in the early Soviet Union, this  is not particularly surprising, given the long list of Bolshevik atrocities. Though it may have been surprising to HIM, in view of the USSR’s official atheism.']])]

[('And caught by the first rays of dawn', [['If a sailor was lost at sea, the only sure way of finding their direction was to find the north star. Some wait for the waters of fortune to cover them
Some just see the tides of ill chance running over them', [['The Age of Reason valued logic and rationality above all else. However, the chorus argues that rationality will give you “no reprieve.” This verse changes tack, and instead looks at chance and fortune. Pessimistically, neither course brings success. The “man for all seasons” is “lost behind the sun,” while those looking for luck see “the tides of ill chance running over them.”']]), ('Lanterns to turn back the night', [['The Age of Reason was also known as the Age of Enlightenment. Since then, “light” or brightness has become synonymous with the good or rational, and darkness has become representative of evil or chaos. Their gains are seen as points of light (instances of goodness or rationality) that will combat the chaos and irrationality of the rest of the world.']]), ('Some wait for the boats that still row to Valhallah
Well, you should try to accept what the fates are unfolding', [['Valhalla is the grand hall in Norse mythology where great warriors are sent when they die. In contrast to the previous lines, this references older “pagan” religions that held sway in Europe before Christianity. Similarly, the fates, another set of older gods, are portrayed as the ones with real power.']]), ('Some call on Jehovah
Some cry out to Allah', [['Jehovah refers to the God of Christianity and Judaism, while Allah is the Muslim God.  In the time period of the play, this would have encompassed the religions of basically everyone in England at the time. Even though the play spends a great deal of time with the split of Western Christianity into Catholic and Protestant, Stewart only mentions one Christian God, perhaps making a comment on lack of differences between the Anglican church and the Catholic church that More died in defense of.']]), ('A sailor through the darkness
He scans the meridian', [['The meridian is an imaginary plane in the sky, tracing a line in the sky from north to south. For a sailor, it would have been used for navigation, and would have been important at night when trying to find the north star.']]), ('While the man for all seasons
Is lost behind the sun', [['The play discusses the battle between conscience and identity. More is presented as a “man for all seasons” in that he keeps his core values through many events and political turmoils. However, More is eventually beheaded because he sticks to his principles- he is “lost behind the sun” and (in the next verse) “lost beneath the storm.”']]), ('Only to find there was no reprieve
Would you still be a man for all seasons?', [['This follows the themes of the play, asking if the arrival of a world completely ruled by natural law and logic (and age of reason) would allow individuals to retain their core beliefs. The lack of reprieve means that this “age of reason,” for all its logic, would not free individuals from conscience (another one of the themes dealt with in the play.)']]), ('What if you reached the age of reason', [['Also known as the Age of Rationalism, the Age of Reason was the philosophical precursor to the Enlightenment (or simply the beginning of the Enlightenment, depending on your perspective). Notable philosophers included Locke, Hobbes, and Descartes. This era focused on the use of logic and deductive reasoning as a means of organizing society.']])]

annotation:
[('If you don’t show, I’m sorry for the pain
 I caused you', [['Here alluding to the horrible tortures a captured spy was liable to face, especially if, given the time period, the spy’s enemies are indeed Nazis.']]), ('I really wouldn’t ask if there was anybody else
 But I know you’ve got the knack of taking care of yourself', [['Of course the speaker IS asking if the man he is meeting brought any “muscle” with him for protection.']]), ('When you get the paper take a look inside
 On page twenty-seven there’s a photo of a bride
 Underneath the story of a man who died
 In Morocco', [['Even the newspaper publisher is in cahoots with the enemy and prints a bogus article that encodes a secret message.

PROPOSED SUGGESTION: References to the KGB here and elsewhere are incorrect. Al Stewart’s concept album is about the period between World War One and World War Two (“between the wars”), not the Cold War, which followed World War Two.

Moreover, “Night Train to Munich” both references and takes its title from the 1940 film by director Carol Reed about a British spy infiltrating Nazi Germany to rescue a scientist and his daughter.

No Russians (then Soviets), no KGB. In fact, in 1940, when the movie was released, the Nazis and the Soviets were “allies” after signing the Molotov-Ribbentrop Pact in August 1939 that promised mutual non-aggression, ultimately broken when Germany invaded the USSR in June 1941.']]), ('And there will be a stain on his tunic
 A paper underneath his arm', [['The conductor is part of the spy organization as well, and is using these devices to be recognized.']]), ('Meet me at the station underneath the clock
 Carry an umbrella, no need to talk', [['The ballad begins by explaining that this is about one spy meeting another. They don’t know each other by sight, so the one being addressed here will carry an umbrella so as to be recognized. Presumably nobody else at that station under that clock would be carrying an umbrella at that time.']]), ('Then you’d better pray that he doesn’t look away
 Or you’ll never, never, never come back', [['This echoes the line in “Roads To Moscow”, “I wonder when I’ll be home again and the morning answers ‘never’”.

In both cases, the KGB has total power to “disappear” anyone they don’t like.']]), ('The man in the homburg', [['The characteristic men’s hat of the 1940s, familiar from all the old movies.']])]

While the singer moves around like an Elvis clone
They really packed them in
And every song was short and sweet, and every beat was fast
And every paper in the land said rock-and-roll won't last
You know it just won't last, it's such a rapid burn
And it's a hard, hard, hard lesson to learn
It's a hard, hard, hard lesson to learn

Well what are you going to do when it's all over?
What are you going to do right now?
What are you going to to when it's all over?
Will you get along somehow?
I just don't know
Feeling like I do right now
Ask me tomorrow

Red guitar, red guitar
You know I really miss that red guitar
Red guitar, red guitar
You know I reallly miss that red guitar

And you can write this on my tombstone
That'll be my fate
I'm a gradute of rock-and-roll
Class of '58
You might also like'58, '58, I'm a graduate of the class of '58
Red guitar, '58, I'm a graduate of the class of '58

And there's no use analyzing these anthems that were sung
Rock-and-roll's not good or bad
It's just the sound of being young
And it's a long long way from pompadours
And doo-wop and payola
And one day they'll make TV shows on aging rock-and-rollers
One day they'llmakeTV shows on aging rock-and-rollersEmbed

title: Out in the Snow
lyrics:
Out in the Snow LyricsI walked out in the snow
And left no mark upon the ground I trod
The sky, heavy and low
The exhalation of an Arctic god
And I heard words meant for no one
In the air,words out of nowhere
And I saw all at once at my feet
Unexpectedly, a shadow play

I broke off on a floe
And drifted aimlessly a hundred miles
The wind, beginning to blow
Carried me forward on this boat of ice
And I saw things half imagined
Far away, pictures and pageants
That were lost in a moment like words
From a langauge that I never knew
And this voyage seemed to be haunted
By a soul, lost and unwanted
Destined to journey through time
Always covered in a coat of white

I walked out in the snow
Never knowing what I came here for
A dream from so long ago
But we don't talk about it anymoreYou might also likeEmbed

title: My Egyptian Couch
lyrics:
My Egyptian Couch LyricsNow here's a book full of photographs
That my ancestors made some generations ago
They're wearing the lastest clothes in a nautical way
The Suez Canal close behind is frozen in time
The deck crews star out of a mime
And they seem to be considering me
Here on my Egyptian couch

O the life on Edwardian steamships
Is measured and slow, while down below
There are fires that shudder and clang and thunder
And sweat-caked in smoke, and cauldrons to stoke
To send the ship on her way
Tasting the salt and the spray
And a century later I scan the equator
From my Egyptian couch
And the news every day brings
Contains the strangest of things
But with confident smilesw my forebears decline
To gaze into the wings

So they look from the photographs
And they're curious now, wondering how we turned out
Let's say like the Chinese adage
We're living our lives in interesting timesYou might also likeEmbed

annotation:
[('But still the shadow that the night won’t free
 Just follows wherever you go', [['The Midas shadow seems to be a compulsion to turn everything someone touches into gold – for instance while gambling. Even after a successful night of gambling (in which the person being described ‘stole the game so easily’), the urge to keep on gambling follows them wherever they go.']]), ('Jackdaw', [['The jackdaw is a bird in the crow family. Like magpies (another bird in the crow family), jackdaws are known to show interest in shiny objects (e.g., jewellery). ‘Jackdaw reasons’ presumably refers to someone being interested in shiny objects (such as gold) just for the sake it.']]), ('Conquistador', [['Conquistador is Spanish and Portuguese for ‘conqueror’. The term is used to refer to soldiers of the Spanish and Portuguese Empires. In the 15th to 18th centuries, they conquered territory, opened trade routes and colonised part of the world.']]), ('Midas', [['King Midas is a Greek mythological figure.

Dionysus – the Greek god of wine, fertility, vegetation, ecstasy and festivity – granted Midas a wish. Midas asked that everything he touches would turn into gold, an ability he initially enjoys. But when Midas sits down to eat and finds that even the food on his table turns into gold (and thereby becomes inedible) when he touches it, he regrets his wish and asks Dionysus for it be reverted. Dionysus tells him to wash in the river Pactolus. When Midas does so, the river sands turn into gold.']])]

annotation:
[('Our time is wasting in the wind', [['When this line is sung, the guitar melody interrupts the vocal line between “our time” and “is wasting in the wind.” The melody sounds a lot like wind, and gives the aural effect of interrupting time with a gust of wind, mirroring the meaning of the line.']]), ('Marat your days are numbered', [['Jean-Paul Marat was a journalist and political scientist active during the French Revolution. He supported the sans-culottes, a radical left-wing group made up primarily of urban laborers, who argued for political and economic equality for the urban poor. His support of this faction aided the decline of the Girondins (another revolutionary faction). When they fell from power, one of their members sought revenge and killed Marat while he was taking a bath.']]), ('Oh you sit and talk all through the night
 But there’s just no place to go', [['The beginning of the French Revolution was largely controlled by the new middle class (merchants and lawyers dissatisfied with their relegation to the Third Estate), and philosophers influenced by the Age of Enlightenment. These philosophers led the more conservative beginnings of the Revolution, publishing the Declaration of the Rights of Man and placing an emphasis on the ideas of the revolution- “talk[ing] all though the night.”

As the revolution progressed, and was met with the bloody violence of the Reign of Terror, these philosophers would have felt increasingly trapped, both intellectually and politically.']]), ('The ghost of revolution
 Still prowls the Paris streets', [['Although the French revolution didn’t succeed in expanding full equality to all members of the third estate, it make some lasting reforms. They did succeed in limiting the powers of the monarchy, although they did not end the monarchy itself (it resurfaced fully after the death of Napoleon II).

One of the most important reforms was Napoleon’s institution of a consistent, written legal code, which he enforced throughout his empire.']]), ('It speaks inside the cheap red wine
 Of cafe summer nights
 Its red and amber voices
 Call the cars at traffic lights', [['Here the imagery jumps from the late 18th century to modern times. Red wine and cafes are often associated with the stereotypical idea of Paris, and mention of cars completes the urban scenery. The “red and amber voices” makes the scene less ordinary, as if the “ghost of revolution” is the one whispering.']]), ('Down all the restless centuries
 It wanders incomplete', [['In the same way that the American Revolution influenced the ideas set fourth in the French Revolution, the French Revolution influenced and inspired other revolutions in colonies around the world. The “restless centuries” would refer to the other future revolutions it inspires, while it would be considered incomplete because neither the French Revolution or the other later revolutions fully succeeded.']]), ('Inside the midnight councils
 The lamps are burning low', [['These lines reference the National Assemblies that convened to abolish the absolute monarchy. Most important was their “Declaration of the Rights of Man,” which drew on the ideas set forth in the Constitution to secure basic rights for the non-aristocratic.

This could also refer to the later Constituent Assembly, which declared the right to self-determination, or the 1792 Convention, which established the republic.']]), ('It echoes
 Through the lonely palace of Versailles', [['After Louis XVI was forced from Versailles in 1789 (taken to Paris to feel the suffering of the common man), Versailles would have been left empty as the rest of the aristocracy tried to seem as nonexistent as possible.']]), ('We burned out their mansions
 In the name of Robespierre', [['Robespierre oversaw the later, more radical stage of the French revolution. This time period was known as the Reign of Terror, and was characterized by the many beheadings- mainly of aristocracy, but also of those who fell behind the radicalism of the revolution. As the aristocracy fled the country, or were executed, their property and possessions would have been seized as mob rule gained more weight than law.']]), ('The Kings have all departed
 There servants are nowhere', [['By October 1789 the King and his family were forced out of Versailles and made to go to Paris where a new Constitution was being drafted. Versailles was seen as a symbol of their luxury and isolation, so they were sent to Paris to remind them of the struggles of the common people.

By 1791 the French king was so worried by the revolution that he decided to flee the country. He fled with his family to allies at a military camp in Northern France, but was recognized and captured before reaching safety (one of the downsides to putting your likeness on every coin in the country). He and his wife, Marie Antoinette, were captured and returned to Paris, where they were later beheaded.



Source.']])]

annotation:
[('Marie Celeste', [['The Mary Celeste was an American merchant vessel which was discovered adrift and desert in the Atlantic Ocean of the Azores Islands in 1872. Many hypothesis such as mutiny, piracy or natural causes were advanced, which reached no clear conclusion.

Due to its mysterious outcome, Sir Arthur Conan Doyle wrote a short story based on the vessel, which misspelled its name as ‘Marie Celeste’, just like Al Stewart mentions in this verse.']]), ('Oh come away from the day, here I stay
 Living on the bottom of the sea', [['At significant depths in the ocean, there is no light- the water blocks any rays of sunlight.

Light may be detected as far as 1,000 meters down in the ocean, but there is rarely any significant light beyond 200 meters.

American nuclear submarines have a crush depth of 490 meters, though other civilian submarines would have weaker hulls. These depths are still far below that of complete darkness, however.

Source.']])]

title: Old Admirals
lyrics:
Old Admirals LyricsI can well recall the first time I ever put to sea
It was on the old "Calcutta" in eighteen fifty-three
I was just a lad of fourteen years, a midshipman to be
To make my way in sailing ships of the Royal Navy

By the time that I was twenty-one I'd sailed the world around
Weathered storms in the China seas with the hatches battened down
And made my way by starlight off the coast of Newfoundland
And dined on beer and herrings while the waves blew all around

I live in retirement now and through my window comes the sound
Of seagulls and sets my mind remembering
The evening stars like memories sail far beyond the distant trees
Way out across the open seas I hear them sing
Oh, the wooden ships they turned to iron and the iron ships to steel
And shed their sails like autumn leaves with the turning of the wheel
And I was given Captain's rank, and soon took under me
The proudest ship that ever sailed for Queen and country

Ah, the old queen she passed away with the newborn century
And I received my calling up to the admiralty
The sands ran through the hourglass each day more rapidly
As we watched the growing of the fleets of High Germany

So at last the Great War blazed I waited with the passing days
A call to arms that never came, writing letters
"I may be old now in your eyes, but all my years have made me wise
You don't see where the danger lies, oh call me back, call me back..."

But the war, it ran its course they could find no use for me
And I live in the country now, grandchildren on my knee
And sometimes think in all this world the saddest thing to be
Old admirals who feel the wind and never put to sea

Now just like you, I've sailed my dreams like ships across the sea
And some of them they've come on rocks and some faced mutiny
And when they're sunken one by one I'll join that company -
Old admirals who feel the wind, and never put to seaYou might also likeEmbed

title: A Long Way Down From Stephanie
lyrics:
A Long Way Down From Stephanie LyricsMaid, truly I see
Now it must be a long way down
And with love's burnt shore
Must all dalliance hither
Crumble and wither

Oh strange
Methought it strange
Thou couldst deprive me of my crown
Thou cast upon me as linden bears fruit of bitter strain
And I would go forsooth to the dragon's tooth
If thus a chance were gained
To resurrect that part of your wanton heart
To whose grave my own is chained

And hold, ere thou dost go
Were not thy moments gilded too?
And in honesty didst thou not measure for measure
Countenance pleasure?

Cold wert thou so cold
Lest thy mind be frozen too
And will not spring be reborn
But might the sun for the frost here
That all be not lost herein

And I would rather, zounds
It were hell's own hounds
Whose foul breath upon my face
Did portent my doom
Than to bear the gloom
Of a world stripped of thy grace

And so in truth I know
Yes it will be a long way down
And if go thou must
Ere we should meet accidental
Prithee be gentle
And though distant now
Perchance the hand of time may soothe
And though lost at six
If I should live to be seven I might forget StephanieYou might also likeEmbed

title: A Man for All Seasons
lyrics:
A Man For All Seasons Lyrics[Chorus]
What if you reached the age of reason
Only to find there was no reprieve
Would you still be a man for all seasons?
Or would you just have to leave
[Verse 1]
We measure our days out
In steps of uncertainty
Not turning to see how we've come
And peer down the highway
From here to eternity
And reach out for love on the run
While the man for all seasons
Is lost behind the sun
[Verse 2]
Henry Plantagenet still looks for someone
To bring good news in his hour of doubt
While Thomas More waits in the Tower of London
Watching the sands running out
And measures the hours out
From here to oblivion
In actions that can't be undone
A sailor through the darkness
He scans the meridian
And caught by the first rays of dawn
The man for all seasons
Is lost beneath the storm

[Verse 3]
And I should know by now
I should know by now
I hear them call it out all around
Oh, they go
There's nothing to believe in
Hear them
Just daydreams, deceiving
They'll just let you down

[Chorus]
What if you reached the age of reason
Only to find there was no reprieve
Would you still be a man for all seasons?
Or would you just disbelieve?
You might also like[Verse 4]
We measure our gains out in luck and coincidence
Lanterns to turn back the night
And put our defeats down to chance or experience
And try once again for the light
Some wait for the waters of fortune to cover them
Some just see the tides of ill chance running over them

[Verse 5]
Some call on Jehovah
Some cry out to Allah
Some wait for the boats that still row to Valhallah
Well, you should try to accept what the fates are unfolding
While some say they're sure where the blame should be falling
You look round for maybe a chance of forestalling
But too soon its over and done
And the man for all seasons
Is lost behind the sun4Embed
annotation:
[('And caught by the first rays of dawn', [['If a sailor was lost at sea, the only sure way of finding their direction was to find the north star. The sailor is scanning the meridian to try to find this north star. When he is “caught by the first rays of dawn,” if means that he will no longer be able to find the star and get back on course. Despite his science and logic, he is still lost.



(A reference for the next time you’re lost at sea.)']]), ('The man for all seasons
Is lost beneath the storm', [['The storm refers to the rise of Protestantism, while the sun would refer to Henry VIII, who ordered his beheading.

Sir Thomas Moore was seen as a “man for all seasons” for his ability to maintain a political career in tumultuous times, but even he is eventually swept away by the storm.']]), ('And put our defeats down to chance or experience
And try once again for the light
Some wait for the waters of fortune to cover them
Some just see the tides of ill chance running over them', [['The Age of Reason valued logic and rationality above all else. However, the chorus argues that rationality will give you “no reprieve.” This verse changes tack, and instead looks at chance and fortune. Pessimistically, neither course brings success. The “man for all seasons” is “lost behind the sun,” while those looking for luck see “the tides of ill chance running over them.”']]), ('Lanterns to turn back the night', [['The Age of Reason was also known as the Age of Enlightenment. Since then, “light” or brightness has become synonymous with the good or rational, and darkness has become representative of evil or chaos. Their gains are seen as points of light (instances of goodness or rationality) that will combat the chaos and irrationality of the rest of the world.']]), ('Some wait for the boats that still row to Valhallah
Well, you should try to accept what the fates are unfolding', [['Valhalla is the grand hall in Norse mythology where great warriors are sent when they die. In contrast to the previous lines, this references older “pagan” religions that held sway in Europe before Christianity. Similarly, the fates, another set of older gods, are portrayed as the ones with real power.']]), ('Some call on Jehovah
Some cry out to Allah', [['Jehovah refers to the God of Christianity and Judaism, while Allah is the Muslim God.  In the time period of the play, this would have encompassed the religions of basically everyone in England at the time. Even though the play spends a great deal of time with the split of Western Christianity into Catholic and Protestant, Stewart only mentions one Christian God, perhaps making a comment on lack of differences between the Anglican church and the Catholic church that More died in defense of.']]), ('A sailor through the darkness
He scans the meridian', [['The meridian is an imaginary plane in the sky, tracing a line in the sky from north to south. For a sailor, it would have been used for navigation, and would have been important at night when trying to find the north star.']]), ('While the man for all seasons
Is lost behind the sun', [['The play discusses the battle between conscience and identity. More is presented as a “man for all seasons” in that he keeps his core values through many events and political turmoils. However, More is eventually beheaded because he sticks to his principles- he is “lost behind the sun” and (in the next verse) “lost beneath the storm.”']]), ('Only to find there was no reprieve
Would you still be a man for all seasons?', [['This follows the themes of the play, asking if the arrival of a world completely ruled by natural law and logic (and age of reason) would allow individuals to retain their core beliefs. The lack of reprieve means that this “age of reason,” for all its logic, would not free individuals from conscience (another one of the themes dealt with in the play.)']]), ('What if you reached the age of reason', [['Also known as the Age of Rationalism, the Age of Reason was the philosophical precursor to the Enlightenment (or simply the beginning of the Enlightenment, depending on your perspective). Notable philosophers included Locke, Hobbes, and Descartes. This era focused on the use of logic and deductive reasoning as a means of organizing society.']])]

title: The Palace of Versailles
lyrics:
The Palace of Versailles Lyrics[Verse 1]
The wands of smoke are rising
From the walls of the Bastille
And through the streets of Paris
Runs a sense of the unreal

[Verse 2]
The Kings have all departed
There servants are nowhere
We burned out their mansions
In the name of Robespierre
[Chorus]
And still we wait
To see the day begin
Our time is wasting in the wind
Wondering why
Wondering why, it echoes
Through the lonely palace of Versailles

[Verse 3]
Inside the midnight councils
The lamps are burning low
Oh you sit and talk all through the night
But there's just no place to go

[Verse 4]
And Bonaparte is coming
With his army from the south
Marat your days are numbered
And we live hand to mouth

[Chorus]
While we wait
To see the day begin
Our time is wasting in the wind
Wondering why
Wondering why, it echoes
Through the lonely palace of Versailles
You might also like[Verse 5]
The ghost of revolution
Still prowls the Paris streets
Down all the restless centuries
It wanders incomplete

[Verse 6]
It speaks inside the cheap red wine
Of cafe summer nights
Its red and amber voices
Call the cars at traffic lights

[Chorus]
Why do you wait
To see the day begin
Your time is wasting in the wind
Wondering why
Wondering why, it echoes
Through the lonely palace of Versailles

[Outro]
Wondering why, it echoes
Through the lonely palace of Versailles1Embed
annotation:
[('Our time is wasting in the wind', [['When this line is sung, the guitar melody interrupts the vocal line between “our time” and “is wasting in the wind.” The melody sounds a lot like wind, and gives the aural effect of interrupting time with a gust of wind, mirroring the meaning of the line.']]), ('Marat your days are numbered', [['Jean-Paul Marat was a journalist and political scientist active during the French Revolution. He supported the sans-culottes, a radical left-wing group made up primarily of urban laborers, who argued for political and economic equality for the urban poor. His support of this faction aided the decline of the Girondins (another revolutionary faction). When they fell from power, one of their members sought revenge and killed Marat while he was taking a bath.']]), ('Oh you sit and talk all through the night
 But there’s just no place to go', [['The beginning of the French Revolution was largely controlled by the new middle class (merchants and lawyers dissatisfied with their relegation to the Third Estate), and philosophers influenced by the Age of Enlightenment. These philosophers led the more conservative beginnings of the Revolution, publishing the Declaration of the Rights of Man and placing an emphasis on the ideas of the revolution- “talk[ing] all though the night.”

As the revolution progressed, and was met with the bloody violence of the Reign of Terror, these philosophers would have felt increasingly trapped, both intellectually and politically.']]), ('The ghost of revolution
 Still prowls the Paris streets', [['Although the French revolution didn’t succeed in expanding full equality to all members of the third estate, it make some lasting reforms. They did succeed in limiting the powers of the monarchy, although they did not end the monarchy itself (it resurfaced fully after the death of Napoleon II).

One of the most important reforms was Napoleon’s institution of a consistent, written legal code, which he enforced throughout his empire.']]), ('It speaks inside the cheap red wine
 Of cafe summer nights
 Its red and amber voices
 Call the cars at traffic lights', [['Here the imagery jumps from the late 18th century to modern times. Red wine and cafes are often associated with the stereotypical idea of Paris, and mention of cars completes the urban scenery. The “red and amber voices” makes the scene less ordinary, as if the “ghost of revolution” is the one whispering.']]), ('Down all the restless centuries
 It wanders incomplete', [['In the same way that the American Revolution influenced the ideas set fourth in the French Revolution, the French Revolution influenced and inspired other revolutions in colonies around the world. The “restless centuries” would refer to the other future revolutions it inspires, while it would be considered incomplete because neither the French Revolution or the other later revolutions fully succeeded.']]), ('Inside the midnight councils
 The lamps are burning low', [['These lines reference the National Assemblies that convened to abolish the absolute monarchy. Most important was their “Declaration of the Rights of Man,” which drew on the ideas set forth in the Constitution to secure basic rights for the non-aristocratic.

This could also refer to the later Constituent Assembly, which declared the right to self-determination, or the 1792 Convention, which established the republic.']]), ('It echoes
 Through the lonely palace of Versailles', [['After Louis XVI was forced from Versailles in 1789 (taken to Paris to feel the suffering of the common man), Versailles would have been left empty as the rest of the aristocracy tried to seem as nonexistent as possible.']]), ('We burned out their mansions
 In the name of Robespierre', [['Robespierre oversaw the later, more radical stage of the French revolution. This time period was known as the Reign of Terror, and was characterized by the many beheadings- mainly of aristocracy, but also of those who fell behind the radicalism of the revolution. As the aristocracy fled the country, or were executed, their property and possessions would have been seized as mob rule gained more weight than law.']]), ('The Kings have all departed
 There servants are nowhere', [['By October 1789 the King and his family were forced out of Versailles and made to go to Paris where a new Constitution was being drafted. Versailles was seen as a symbol of their luxury and isolation, so they were sent to Paris to remind them of the struggles of the common people.

By 1791 the French king was so worried by the revolution that he decided to flee the country. He fled with his family to allies at a military camp in Northern France, but was recognized and captured before reaching safety (one of the downsides to putting your likeness on every coin in the country). [('And where we left it before they took it

 Well, I watched it and I didn’t say nothing
 And now I’m crying when I sleep
 Now I’m sayin’, I’m prayin’, to that sweet melody in my soul', [['Brittany, continuing to ask herself the question of why can’t boys and girls be friends, reminisces on the times that they had together. The person that broke their friendship up with this comment has ruined their past relationship. This still resonates with her to this day, as they still try to fix their friendship, but all has come too late.']]), ('Oh why don’t you call?
 Don’t you care anymore?
 It’s not fair
 Don’t let ’em get you
 It took us both and now I got to fix you
 Well, I don’t know how to fix you
 You say it’s just the way it is to be, and how so?', [['Brittany attempts to bring them back together, after people have brought their friendship down, just for the sole fact that they are of opposing genders.

She perilously tries to fix what has been broken, which she continues with on later, but two are needed to make a relationship work, even just in a platonic way.

She goes on to say that the fact that they were mocked as teenagers for being best friends had broken them both apart. She tries to fix them, but doesn’t know how because she’s never known.']]), ('Oh, why can’t you see that I’m not trying to be
 No kind of bother I’m just trying
 To save what was left between you and me', [['Since Brittany had been told as a kid that boys can’t be friends with girls, her life has been shaped and her relationships have been damaged. Especially with the ‘boy’ she is singing about, whose relationship with Brittany has fallen apart.

She desperately tries to keep their relationship strong, but is losing hope, because he doesn’t help her with her perils.']]), ('Oh why can’t we be best friends anymore?
 They say a friend ain’t to be
 Between a girl and a boy
 I don’t know who said it
 Or why it got to be so wrong', [['Starting off the song and it’s message, Brittany  relives the past to her teenage years, where she had been mocked for having a boy for a best friend.

This question carries on throughout the song, as she desperately tries to find who told her this, which has shaped her life.

Contrastingly, she has found comfort in Alabama Shakes, who are all males, but her. They have released 2 albums and toured all over the world and become best friends, through the world of music.']]), ('Why
 Is an awful lot of question
 And I can’t give me no answer
 I keep wondering on', [['The age old question of ‘can boys be friends with girls’ has been circulating in people’s minds since the dawn of time. There are many reasons why this platonic type of relationship cannot work, which is often seen within popular culture, including being in a friendship without sexual interactions to being complete polar opposites to each other.

This is the question that Brittany asks throughout this song, because she needs answers as to why she can’t be friends with this boy.

As stated before, in her younger years, she was told that boys and girls cannot be friends. The song follows her attempts at finding these answers. In an interview with NME Music, Brittany said that she had been mocked as a teen for having a boy as a best friend.']])]

annotation:
[('Not far now
 Not far now
 Not far now
 Far, far now
 Far, far, far, far now
 Far, far, far, far out', [['These lines reflect on how the astronaut is increasingly far from home on his journey in search of a new Earth. As the distance increases, the journey becomes more and more a path of no return.
Notice how she goes from “not far now” to “far, far out”, playing with the distance traveled over time by the astronaut in the way she arranges and repeats the words.
Until the last line, the bridge is like a lullaby for the astronaut’s 500 years hibernation. And then there is an emphasis on “far out”, with an abrupt change in the vocals pitch, that are quickly cut off.  As if the traveler is suddenly startled when he awakes and realizes that it’s too late now. He can’t go back home.']]), ('Sound and color
 With me, for my mind', [['“Sound & Color” takes on the journey of an astronaut who has been put into ‘cryosleep’ on a space mission. As he wakes, he discovers that it has been 500 years since he left Earth, and experiences nostalgic flashbacks of his time on Earth.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=faG8RiaANek

As for the phrase, ‘sound & color’, Alabama Shakes have created a recurring motif from it throughout the song, as a figment of the astronaut’s memories. His memories and flashbacks are vivid, including sounds and colors associated with them, as he attempts to re-orient himself with this reality.

The astronaut’s ability to relive these memories in his head loosely represents the ‘neurological abnormality disorder’, synesthesia, where one can experience sounds and colors in extremely different ways, sometimes being linked to memories of the past.']]), ('No more to see the setting of the sun', [['The song (and music video) is framed from the perspective of an astronaut lost in space. This gives the listener (or viewer) the allusion that the singer feels estranged from humanity.

The astronaut longs to go back to the simple pleasures of life that he / she knew before becoming distanced from others, like seeing a sunrise or just being in close contact with someone.']]), ('A new world hangs
 Outside the window
 Beautiful and strange
 It must be I’ve fallen awake
 I must be', [['Brittany Howard on “Sound & Color”:

I started writing about an astronaut that was sent on a mission to find a new Earth. And they put him to sleep… And he wakes up and everything’s wrong. Everything’s chaotic. Everything’s different.

The official music video shows an explicit story line, similar to what Brittany states in the podcast aforementioned, however, the underlying message Brittany presents is much deeper. This is a message of hope and “new beginnings”, which society goes through, assisted with “sound” and “color”.

This message links with the band’s album, as they go through “new beginnings”, as well as them being “free to do what [they] want to do as musicians”.']]), ('Ain’t life just awful strange?', [['Feelings of existentialism, though certainly open for interpretation. It allows the listener to reflect on their own life and all of it’s oddities.

Going back to the astronaut, Brittany may be saying that after waking up and realising how amazing and strange life was, he wishes he didn’t give it all away on his long and unsuccessful space mission.

While on Earth the astronaut didn’t appreciate the beauty and peculiarity of “ordinary life”. After losing everything on Earth he can finally see the true value of what he had.']]), ('I wanna touch a human being', [['Brittany Howard explained in an interview on NPR that this song is about an astronaut that wakes up after 500 years in hypersleep to find that he’s all alone. This line shows his anger and loneliness in isolation and a desire to go back in hypersleep so he can end his loneliness.']])]

Sometimes. when everybody acts like they need to be told that everything will be fine, it can lead them to more stress than just admitting that things aren’t so good right now.']]), ('I don’t wanna fight no more', [['After the second verse, it becomes clear that the issues are broader.  She might be fighting with her partner, but more importantly she’s struggling to just make it in life.  The toll is getting to her, and she just wishes she could stop with the daily struggle.']]), ('I don’t wanna fight no more', [['Initially, this seems to be a cry to end the arguing with her partner.']]), ('There ain’t no money left, why can’t I catch my breath?
 I’m gonna work myself to death', [['After all the bills are paid and food is on the table, there is no money left to use on other things. Now she has to go back to work, and it seems like the cycle will never end.']]), ('Living ain’t no fun, the constant dedication
 Keeping the water and power on', [['Running a household is a job in and of itself, but you also need an extra job to keep the luxuries of having a house (such as water and power) in place.']]), ('Attacking, defending
 Until there’s nothing left worth winning', [['They argue back and forth over a petty dispute until the fight isn’t even worth winning anymore; neither of them gain anything from their efforts.']]), ('What you like, what I like
 Why can’t we both be right?', [['Fighting to be right is a really strong thing in human life. We want to have power, show we’re the smarter one. This is showing why can’t we both just forget about this and move on? The Alabama Shakes are a very non-violence type of band with this kinda thing.']]), ('[Verse 1]', [['The verse opens with a shout reminiscent of James Brown, who is a huge influence on the band. However, Brittany has made it clear that she doesn’t “want to copy James Brown” because “I can’t sing like James Brown. I just do the best I can”.

Brittany has done this in multiple songs, especially live, and has become a sort of adlib.']]), ('Your pride and my pride
 Don’t waste my time', [['The desire to ‘be right’ is strong in a relationship. People take stands, “Attacking, defending”, and neither side’s ego/pride will allow them to back down.

She pleas for fairness, “Why can’t we both be right?"but they are beyond that, and she knows this, and she "don’t wanna fight no more”.']]), ('Ooh, my line, your line
 Don’t cross them lines', [['The woman is saying that their lives are separate and to stay out of each other’s business.']])]

annotation:
[('And listen loud', [['Turn up the volume within your mind. Reverting back to the last two lines; you must listen with intensity, and build out your sound from there.']]), ('Imagine the sound', [['Imagine a sound.

The sound I hear most often in my imagination always comes as a whisper. To hear that sound you must concentrate on it and nothing else.

Sometimes I hear the sound whilst walking among the pines. Then I hear the gentle hush of the needles, as the boughs slowly sway to and fro. Often times I hear the sound when at first softly, and then steadily, the skies release their stores from upon high. As the crystalline lace descends to the ground, I hear it saying “shhh” as if upsetting some unseen librarian.

Imagine a sound.']]), ('Listen to teacher', [['The teachers are everyone and everything.

The hardest part of learning is the listening. This world demands to be heard, and filtering out the noise is nearly impossible.']]), ('Some things could be
 Seen from above
 Thread of design
 Don’t trip me up', [['Sometimes, we can look at the life we’re living as if we’ve already done it – like our own personal oracle. If we can be prospective and trace our thread in the fabric of the universe, we can predict where we’ll end up, and act accordingly. Hopefully, we won’t get lost in it all.']]), ('Some want to see
 Those who’ve gone above
 Friends that they’ve lost
 People they love
 
 I’d rather meet
 The me down the road
 To lead me through the fog
 Wouldn’t ask for more', [['If given the chance to see people from the past, present, or future, most people would want to see those from the past. That is, old friends, old flames, and souls departed. But Brittany Howard wants to see someone from the future – herself. Maybe her future self can guide her through the unclear, foggy road that lies ahead.']]), ('Children
 Take or leave it
 Come, people
 You got to give a little, get a little
 And see it
 Like future you people', [['Society is quick to deride today’s youth, claiming that they’re too immature, inexperienced, and used to getting what they want to really do anything, which leads to an overwhelming sense of apathy among them. The adults tell the kids they’re useless so the kids fail to care about anything, which in turn propagates this notion of uselessness. It’s a vicious cycle and a self-fulfilling prophecy.

Howard pleads to the youth of today—many of whom are listening to her music—to start imagining themselves as the adults of tomorrow, and to begin working hard and caring about the world around them today.']])]

 Tell me, I bet you didn’t do nothing wrong
 Tell me, what’s been going on?', [['She feels that the things that she’s hearing about her partner aren’t true; she knows him, and despite his behavior and his addiction, she thinks he didn’t do any of it.

Love is said to be blinding; that it makes people overlook certain negative traits in other people. This is especially true if you have certain things distracting you, such as the couple’s shared addiction to crystal meth.']]), ('Well, is it true?

 Well, are they sure?

“Consistent use of crystal meth can result in severe anxiety, paranoid and insomnia. Additionally, thoughts of suicide—or even homicide—have been noted in some meth abusers.”

It’s possible that the narrator’s partner had begun experiencing the aforementioned symptoms and committed some kind of offense, and when she hears about this, she hesitates to believe it. However, it’s also possible that she is experiencing paranoia about her partner as an addict herself.']]), ('And your Mickey Mouse tattoo
 And you’ll be leaving in your Honda Accord', [['Asked if the Mickey Mouse tattoo and Honda Accord are real, Howard told Uncut:

“Well, the Mickey Mouse tattoo is. I had to change the car because it was a very specific type and I tried not to give everything away.”']]), ('Maybe the stars aligned, or maybe I’ve just changed my mind

 Yes', [['Destiny and fate are usually linked with the stars aligning and often represents people being in the right place at the right time.

Howard seems to convince herself that she belongs to her ex after all. She builds up from a passive, “Maybe I’m yours,” to a more decisive “I’m yours, yea yea.”']])]

annotation: [('Atlanta was on fire and so was she the night he left her\n Left her there to bear her pain alone\n Hoping soon to return, burn, Georgia, burn', [['Anyone who has sat through an American history class is probably familiar with this reference to the Siege of Atlanta as a part of Sherman’s March to Sea in the Civil War. annotation:
[('Then I’ll float on down the river
 To a Cajun hideaway', [['Like Tom Sawyer when he was floating down the Mississippi River on his raft, He’s referring to his “happy place”. He wants to hear the kind music that gives him a peace of mind and makes him happy. He’s going to stop floating once he gets down south to the Cajun areas of Mississippi and Louisiana.']]), ('Climb a long tall hickory. Bend it over, skinning cats', [['“Skinning cats” is referring to skinning/cleaning catfish, getting them ready to fry.']]), ('That comes from the heart
 Play something with lots of feeling
 Because that’s where music has to start', [['Maybe it’s  Barry White, maybe it’s Hank Williams Sr.. Albeit, two incredibly different musicians, Alabama’s point is, music has to have soul and feeling. These two artists demonstrate this point almost perfectly in their respective genres and music.

Barry White (1944-2003)



Hank Williams Sr. (1923-1953)']]), ('Take a nap like Rip Van Winkle, daze dreaming again', [['“Rip Van Winkle” is a short story by Washington Irving from the early 1800s. It’s set in New York’s Catskill Mountains, where a bridge between Hudson and Catskill still holds the eponymous protagonist’s name.

In the prose, Van Winkle drinks moonshine and falls asleep … for a VERY long time. He awakes to find his son grown up. It’s very similar conceit to Brendan Fraser’s 1999 hit film Blast from the Past – and today Irving’s story is literally a blast from the past.



– Van Winkle in a 19th century stage adaptation.']]), ('Play some back-home, come-on music', [["Not c'mon … rather come on as in the kinda music that gets you in da mood for love."]]), ('Playing baseball with chert rocks, using sawmill slabs for bats', [['Baseball is America’s Pastime. However, it seems as if the narrator did not play with Rawlings and Wilson equipment, but instead with chert rocks (silica) and rough-hewn lumber. Sounds painful!']]), ('Oh, play me some mountain music
 Like grandma and grandpa used to play', [['Mountain music is the grittiest Country music imaginable. Referring to the Appalachian mountains that run down the east coast. Mountain music is made with fiddles, guitar, banjos, mandolins, and all types of percussion.']]), ('Drift away like Tom Sawyer, ride a raft with old Huck Finn', [['A reference to two different Mark Twain novels, “The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn” and “The Adventures of Tom Sawyer”.



It’s not the only time “Tom Sawyer” has been mentioned in music!
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Eh_9NY56Sxw']])]

[('Don’t know why
 I have to drive so fast', [['Some people can become fixated on efficiency. Driving fast can lend some agency to the person. Again we see the theme of not wasting time.']]), ('All I really gotta do is live and die

However still feels a subconscious urge to be moving/achieving']]), ('I’m in a hurry to get things done
 Oh, I rush and rush until life’s no fun', [['This speaks to shared experience where many people place their value on achieving things or going places. Workaholics and people with strict ideas of what they should be doing lose a lot of the ability so “slow down” relax and have fun.']]), ('But it’ll do 0 to 60 in 5.2, oh', [['“Zero to sixty” is a term meaning to go from a stand still to highway speeds (60 miles per hour). 5.2 is how many seconds his car takes to go from 0 MPH to 60 MPH, which is plenty for consumer grade vehicles, even though modern high end vehicles have beaten this.']])]

annotation:
[('So rosin up that bow for “Faded Love” and let’s all dance
 If you’re gonna play in Texas you gotta have a fiddle in the band', [['A reference to the classic Bob Wills’s song “Faded Love”, which was also covered by Elvis Presley. The melody makes heavy use of the fiddle.']]), ('If you’re gonna play in Texas, you gotta have a fiddle in the band
 That lead guitar is hot but not for a Louisiana man', [['Texans love fiddles, and that’s a fact, hence a “hot guitar” won’t help if you’re going to play there:

During the mid-nineteenth and early twentieth centuries, a distinctive form of fiddle music emerged in Texas. Known for idiosyncratic timing and phrasing, this style was commonly played with banjos or guitars on front porches or in living rooms, less for show and more for social interaction. It reflected the cross-pollination in Texas following the Civil War, with touches of African-American, Appalachian, Cajun, Czech, German, Irish, Mexican, Polish, and Scottish musical forms.']]), ('So we dusted off our boots and put our cowboy hats on straight
 Them Texans raised the roof when Jeff opened up his case
 You say y’all all want to two-step, say you wanna do-si-do
 Well here’s a fiddling song before we go', [['Thanks to the random male’s criticism, the band finally gets to understand what’s missing in their songs: the fiddle.



“Two-step” or “dosados”, often called the “Texas two-step dance”, is a popular western way of dancing to country music.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XRYOqjtfXkc']]), ('I remember down in Houston we were puttin’ on a show
 When a cowboy in the back stood up and yelled “Cotton Eye Joe!”
 He said, ”We love what you’re doing, boys don’t get us wrong
 There’s just something missing in your song”', [['“Cotton Eyed Joe” is a traditional country folklorist song, popular in the southern states which then became famous to the larger public thanks to Rednex’s dance-hall version of the song.  The track requires a prominent use of the fiddle, among all other instruments.']])]

annotation:
[('Then I’ll float on down the river
 To a Cajun hideaway', [['Like Tom Sawyer when he was floating down the Mississippi River on his raft, He’s referring to his “happy place”. He wants to hear the kind music that gives him a peace of mind and makes him happy. He’s going to stop floating once he gets down south to the Cajun areas of Mississippi and Louisiana.']]), ('Climb a long tall hickory. Bend it over, skinning cats', [['“Skinning cats” is referring to skinning/cleaning catfish, getting them ready to fry.']]), ('That comes from the heart
 Play something with lots of feeling
 Because that’s where music has to start', [['Maybe it’s  Barry White, maybe it’s Hank Williams Sr.. Albeit, two incredibly different musicians, Alabama’s point is, music has to have soul and feeling. These two artists demonstrate this point almost perfectly in their respective genres and music.

Barry White (1944-2003)



Hank Williams Sr. (1923-1953)']]), ('Take a nap like Rip Van Winkle, daze dreaming again', [['“Rip Van Winkle” is a short story by Washington Irving from the early 1800s. It’s set in New York’s Catskill Mountains, where a bridge between Hudson and Catskill still holds the eponymous protagonist’s name.

In the prose, Van Winkle drinks moonshine and falls asleep … for a VERY long time. He awakes to find his son grown up. It’s very similar conceit to Brendan Fraser’s 1999 hit film Blast from the Past – and today Irving’s story is literally a blast from the past.



– Van Winkle in a 19th century stage adaptation.']]), ('Play some back-home, come-on music', [["Not c'mon … rather come on as in the kinda music that gets you in da mood for love."]]), ('Playing baseball with chert rocks, using sawmill slabs for bats', [['Baseball is America’s Pastime. However, it seems as if the narrator did not play with Rawlings and Wilson equipment, but instead with chert rocks (silica) and rough-hewn lumber. Sounds painful!']]), ('Oh, play me some mountain music
 Like grandma and grandpa used to play', [['Mountain music is the grittiest Country music imaginable. Referring to the Appalachian mountains that run down the east coast. Mountain music is made with fiddles, guitar, banjos, mandolins, and all types of percussion.']]), ('Drift away like Tom Sawyer, ride a raft with old Huck Finn', [['A reference to two different Mark Twain novels, “The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn” and “The Adventures of Tom Sawyer”.



It’s not the only time “Tom Sawyer” has been mentioned in music!
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Eh_9NY56Sxw']])]

annotation:
[('They oughta get rich man to vote like that', [['(Redacted) unhelpful']]), ('Gone, gone with the wind', [["Gone with the Wind was Margaret Mitchell’s 1936 bestseller about the American South immediately before, during, and shortly after the Civil War. Its movie adaptation, starring Vivien Leigh as Scarlett O'Hara and Clark Gable as Rhett Butler, is still the highest grossing film of all time."]]), ('Song, Song of the south', [['“Song of the South” seems to be a theme for songwriter Bob McDill. In “Good Ole Boys Like Me”, he wrote:

When I was a kid, Uncle Remus put me to bed

Uncle Remus was a popular fictional character introduced in 1880 and made even more famous by the 1946 Disney movie Song of the South, along with the release of children’s books that served as tie-ins to the movie.']]), ('Cotton on roadside, cotton on the ditch
 We all picked the cotton but we never got rich', [['The lyrics depict a poor rural southern farmer whose cash crop ailed them due to the economy at the time.

Cotton prices fell due to new man-made fabrics and cotton dropped from 30 cents a pound in 1919 to 6 cents and below in 1931.']]), ('Well somebody told us Wall Street fell
 But we were so poor that we couldn’t tell', [['October 29th, 1929, commonly referred to as “Black Tuesday”, is the generally accepted date for the beginning of the Great Depression. The prices of stocks plummeted, causing many Americans to lose their life savings.

The songwriter’s family is too poor, and most likely too uninterested, to participate in the stock market, so they literally could not tell the difference between life before and immediately after the Great Depression started.']]), ('Poppa got a job with the TVA
 We bought a washing machine, and then a Chevrolet', [["The Tennessee Valley Authority, or “TVA” for short, was one of many Federal “New Deal” programs created under President Franklin D. Roosevelt. TVA reshaped the South both physically (through the creation of man-made lakes along the Tennessee River) and economically, including the area around the group’s hometown of Fort Payne, AL.

The TVA was established in 1933 and is still active today. Its main purpose was to create jobs in order to help America recover from the Great Depression. The TVA’s practical purpose was primarily to build and maintain several hydroelectric dams to provide flood control and electricity to the Tennessee Valley region.

Vast numbers of Americans suffered major pay cuts or lost their jobs entirely during the Great Depression. Many of the New Deal Programs' main goal was to get Americans back to work in order to jump start the economy.

In the case of the song, “Poppa” was hired by the TVA. Working for them made him enough money to purchase a new vehicle and other goods, which showcases the New Deal Programs' successes in rebounding the economy through increased consumer spending."]]), ('But Mr. Roosevelt’s a’ gonna save us all', [['It’s a sarcastic remark.  Franklin Roosevelt was not very popular in the south, and the feeling was mutual. What galled Southern Democrats was that the “New Deal Democrats” won and held enough seats in Congress to outvote the coalition of Republicans and conservative Southern Democrats.

Those New Deal Democrats, who rode Roosevelt’s coattails into office, were pushing to  strengthen labor unions in much of their legislation, and that irritated both the Republicans and the Southern Democrats.']]), ('Daddy was a veteran, a Southern Democrat', [['Southern Democrats were a political power in the 19th century, and known for opposing the rights of African Americans in the Reconstruction era. Southern Democrats dominated politics in the southern USA from 1820 – 1960.']])]

annotation:
[('They oughta get rich man to vote like that', [['(Redacted) unhelpful']]), ('Gone, gone with the wind', [["Gone with the Wind was Margaret Mitchell’s 1936 bestseller about the American South immediately before, during, and shortly after the Civil War. Its movie adaptation, starring Vivien Leigh as Scarlett O'Hara and Clark Gable as Rhett Butler, is still the highest grossing film of all time."]]), ('Song, Song of the south', [['“Song of the South” seems to be a theme for songwriter Bob McDill. In “Good Ole Boys Like Me”, he wrote:

When I was a kid, Uncle Remus put me to bed

Uncle Remus was a popular fictional character introduced in 1880 and made even more famous by the 1946 Disney movie Song of the South, along with the release of children’s books that served as tie-ins to the movie.']]), ('Cotton on roadside, cotton on the ditch
 We all picked the cotton but we never got rich', [['The lyrics depict a poor rural southern farmer whose cash crop ailed them due to the economy at the time.

Cotton prices fell due to new man-made fabrics and cotton dropped from 30 cents a pound in 1919 to 6 cents and below in 1931.']]), ('Well somebody told us Wall Street fell
 But we were so poor that we couldn’t tell', [['October 29th, 1929, commonly referred to as “Black Tuesday”, is the generally accepted date for the beginning of the Great Depression. The prices of stocks plummeted, causing many Americans to lose their life savings.

The songwriter’s family is too poor, and most likely too uninterested, to participate in the stock market, so they literally could not tell the difference between life before and immediately after the Great Depression started.']]), ('Poppa got a job with the TVA
 We bought a washing machine, and then a Chevrolet', [["The Tennessee Valley Authority, or “TVA” for short, was one of many Federal “New Deal” programs created under President Franklin D. Roosevelt. TVA reshaped the South both physically (through the creation of man-made lakes along the Tennessee River) and economically, including the area around the group’s hometown of Fort Payne, AL.

The TVA was established in 1933 and is still active today. Its main purpose was to create jobs in order to help America recover from the Great Depression. The TVA’s practical purpose was primarily to build and maintain several hydroelectric dams to provide flood control and electricity to the Tennessee Valley region.

Vast numbers of Americans suffered major pay cuts or lost their jobs entirely during the Great Depression. Many of the New Deal Programs' main goal was to get Americans back to work in order to jump start the economy.

In the case of the song, “Poppa” was hired by the TVA. Working for them made him enough money to purchase a new vehicle and other goods, which showcases the New Deal Programs' successes in rebounding the economy through increased consumer spending."]]), ('But Mr. Roosevelt’s a’ gonna save us all', [['It’s a sarcastic remark.  Franklin Roosevelt was not very popular in the south, and the feeling was mutual. What galled Southern Democrats was that the “New Deal Democrats” won and held enough seats in Congress to outvote the coalition of Republicans and conservative Southern Democrats.

Those New Deal Democrats, who rode Roosevelt’s coattails into office, were pushing to  strengthen labor unions in much of their legislation, and that irritated both the Republicans and the Southern Democrats.']]), ('Daddy was a veteran, a Southern Democrat', [['Southern Democrats were a political power in the 19th century, and known for opposing the rights of African Americans in the Reconstruction era. Southern Democrats dominated politics in the southern USA from 1820 – 1960.']])]
